title: In Situ Dewetting and Reactions of Gold-Titanium Bilayers on 2D Materials
content: Study of the interface between two-dimensional (2D) materials and three-dimensional (3D) metallic contacts is of growing importance as 2D materials gain prominence in device applications [1]. The thermal stability of this interface is particularly pertinent in emerging microelectronic and plasmonic devices which are subject to local thermal changes during manufacture or in use. Here, we study a 2D-metal contact designed to withstand such temperature changes by minimising dewetting. The contact is based on nanoislands deposited on 2D materials under ultra-high vacuum (UHV) conditions, producing reproducible, epitaxial interfaces between the 3D islands and 2D materials [2].
